Philosophy of Science || Historical Critique
4.1 Historical Critique


Mach wrote a number of widely read science history texts; in a sense
they are archaeologies of science, digging at the past to critically
elucidate the present. Machian history can also be seen in the context
of German nineteenth century thought; Hegel, David Strauss, Nietzsche,
and Marx all offered historical frameworks for their various
social-philosophical positions. They also saw their own critiques as
playing a crucial role in the new order that was to follow.  That is,
each of their works placed itself at the juncture of history, where
their writing self-consciously was to influence the next stage that it
had predicted. Certainly d’Alembert, Herschel, Whewell, and Mill had
written histories of science before Mach, but it was Mach who wrote
critical history in the above sense.  The interesting aspect of Mach’s
critique was that it actually had an effect upon science. Science
of Mechanics deserves mention in the history of physics.
